awd_titl_txt: Continental-Scale Studies of Mesospheric Dynamics using the Antarctic Gravity Wave Instrument Network (ANGWIN)
awd_abstract_narration:
People are mostly aware of waves that are seen over water surfaces or felt from winds. Similar waves exist in abundance in the atmosphere, affecting many air layers and transporting enormous amount of energy and momentum over large distances; they also affect and sometimes trigger many weather related processes. These waves are called "gravity waves"; they are key drivers of the air general circulation and temperature distributions throughout the middle and upper atmosphere. Studying gravity waves, their sources, generation mechanism and propagation properties, and dynamic characteristics is a matter of high importance for many scientific disciplines including atmospheric science, meteorology, climatology, space weather, and others. Developments in our knowledge and modeling of weather prediction and climate dynamics are of a highest societal importance. 

Although the most significant effects of these gravity waves are best noticeable in the middle- and low latitudes, their generation and initial drivers are better studied from the polar regions. This research continues continent-wide observations of gravity waves in the upper atmosphere over Antarctica through the multinational research effort named ANGWIN (ANtarctic Gravity Wave Instrument Network) that uses state-of-the-art wide field cameras and  Advanced Mesospheric Temperature Mappers (AMTM) deployed at various Antarctic stations. The proposed research adds new imagers to the U.S. stations at Palmer and at McMurdo, augmenting already existing instrumentation strategically distributed around the Antarctic continent at stations Halley and Rothera (UK), Comandante Ferraz (Brazil), Syowa (Japan), Davis (Australia), and at the U.S. stations McMurdo and South Pole. This will create an unprecedented capability for the pan-Antarctic investigations of gravity waves dynamics and their effects on the upper atmosphere. The project will bring new knowledge and better understanding of the continental-scale effects on the general air circulation of the middle and upper atmosphere, quantifying characteristics of mesospheric gravity waves, their dominant sources, propagation, and dissipation over the Antarctic continent and surrounding Southern Ocean. This research is a cost-effective investment that will advance the state of knowledge of the Geospace domain as the arrangement of installed and planned instrumentation will form a powerful observing system with a high potential for advancing this science field. The coordinated analysis of obtained images and data will be performed by the U.S. and international collaborator; data and results will be shared via a series of open workshops, facilitating discussions and assuring progress in understanding of important atmospheric phenomena.

por.por_cntn:
This research grant supported the continued operations and analyses using data from the Antarctic Gravity Wave Instruments Network (ANGWIN). This international program comprises a network of observatories operated by several institutions in a collaborative effort to better understand atmospheric gravity waves (GW) and their effects on the Earth's upper atmosphere over Antarctica. The vast Antarctic continent provides an excellent natural laboratory to detect and measure their properties, motion, and impacts.

These waves continuously propagate energy generated by large weather disturbances into Earth's upper mesosphere (altitude of about 50-70 miles) where they break and deposit this energy, similar to waves breaking on a beach. This energy is most commonly generated by fronts, storms, and strong winds blowing over the Antarctic Peninsula Mountains. The amount produced is significant enough that it can even disrupt modern communications. The continental-scale effects of these waves is becoming clearer as we analyze the remote-sensing measurements being gathered by our ANGWIN GW imaging network across the continent.

This program developed mesospheric GW measurement capabilities at the following sites: McMurdo (US), Syowa (Japan), Davis (Australia), Halley (UK), Rothera (UK), and Commandante Ferraz (Brazil). These international research stations are uniformly distributed around the continental perimeter. Together with our ongoing measurements at the South Pole Station, they provide unprecedented coverage of the Antarctic GW field and its variability during the long polar winter season. We have succeeded in obtaining coordinated data from these field sites for the past six consecutive winters, providing the most comprehensive data set on GW anywhere in the world.

Another outstanding features of the ANGWIN program is that it has brought together scientists and students from institutions around the world in a large-scale, ongoing collaborative effort. To date, the ANGWIN network has conducted four successful research workshops. These workshops have been hosted by The National Institute for Polar Research (NIPR) near Tokyo, Japan (March 2013), Utah State University at Logan, Utah (October 2014), the British Antarctic Survey (BAS) at Cambridge, UK (April 2016), and INPE at São José dos Campos, Brazil (April 2018). A fifth workshop was planned to be hosted by KOPRI in South Korea (2020), but was postponed due to the COVID-19 pandemic. It will be tentatively held in Incheon, South Korea, in September or October 2022. These international workshops have provided scientists, as well as students, excellent opportunities to present and discuss the results of their Antarctic research. As part of this successful program, we hosted two Japanese students at USU for several months and NIPR in Japan hosted one of our USU graduate students for three months, sharing data and new analysis techniques.

In summary, our imaging contribution to the ANGWIN network continues to be very successful, providing a wealth of coordinated GW measurements, which, together with detailed analysis and modeling, will continue to provide a better understanding of the coupling of wave energy into the Earth's near-space environment on a continental-wide scale over Antarctica.
